sn44.11:1.1: At one time Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.
sn44.11:1.2: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta went up to him, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn44.11:1.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and said to Sabhiya Kaccāna:
sn44.11:1.4: “Mister Kaccāna, does a realized one still exist after death?”
sn44.11:1.5: “Vaccha, this has not been declared by the Buddha.”
sn44.11:1.7: “Well then, does a realized one no longer exist after death?”
sn44.11:1.8: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
sn44.11:2.1: “Well then, does a realized one both exist and not exist after death?”
sn44.11:2.2: “This has not been declared by the Buddha.”
sn44.11:2.4: “Well then, does a realized one neither exist nor not exist after death?”
sn44.11:2.5: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
sn44.11:3.1: “Mister Kaccāna, when asked these questions, you say that this has not been declared by the Buddha.
sn44.11:3.13: What’s the cause, what’s the reason why this has not been declared by the Buddha?”
sn44.11:3.14: “In order to describe him as ‘formed’ or ‘formless’ or ‘percipient’ or ‘non-percipient’ or ‘neither percipient nor non-percipient’, there must be some cause or reason for doing so. But if that cause and reason were to totally and utterly cease without anything left over,
sn44.11:3.15: how could you describe him in any such terms?”
sn44.11:3.16: “Mister Kaccāna, how long has it been since you went forth?”
sn44.11:3.18: “Well, you’ve learned a lot already, let alone what lies ahead!”
sn44.11:4.6: The Linked Discourses on undeclared questions are complete.
sn44.11:5.7: The Book of the Six Sense Fields is finished.
